title: Understanding Endometrial Cancer
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value:
Endometrial cancer begins in the lining of the uterus (the endometrium). It is the **most common type of uterine cancer** and often detected early because it causes noticeable symptoms.

Most cases occur after menopause, and early detection leads to excellent treatment outcomes.

content.description: Endometrial cancer is the most common cancer of the female reproductive system.

content.value: Endometrial cancer develops when cells in the uterine lining grow abnormally and form a tumor. Hormonal imbalances, particularly excess estrogen without progesterone, can contribute to its development.

items.title: Type 1 (Endometrioid)
items.description: The most common type, often linked to excess estrogen. Usually slower growing and has a better prognosis.

items.title: Type 2 (Non-endometrioid)
items.description: Less common but more aggressive. Includes serous and clear cell carcinomas.

content.value: Several factors may increase your risk of developing endometrial cancer.

items.title: Hormonal Factors
items.content: Excess estrogen without progesterone, hormone replacement therapy (estrogen only), early menstruation or late menopause, never having been pregnant

items.title: Health Conditions
items.content: Obesity (fat tissue produces estrogen), Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), Type 2 diabetes, Lynch syndrome (hereditary cancer syndrome)

items.title: Other Factors
items.content: Age over 50, family history of endometrial or colon cancer, previous pelvic radiation therapy, tamoxifen use for breast cancer

content.value: Endometrial cancer often shows early warning signs. The most common is abnormal vaginal bleeding.

items: Unusual bleeding or spotting between periods or after menopause
Long, heavy, or frequent bleeding (especially in women over 40)
Thin white or clear vaginal discharge (postmenopausal women)
A lump or mass in the lower abdomen

content.title: Important
content.description: If you experience any of these symptoms, it's important to seek medical evaluation.

content.value: Because symptoms may be similar to other conditions, a thorough evaluation is essential.

steps: Physical exam - checking for lumps or masses in the abdomen
Transvaginal ultrasound - imaging of the uterus and reproductive organs
Endometrial biopsy - taking a tissue sample from the uterus for examination
Dilation & Curettage (D&C) - removing part of the uterine lining for analysis

content.title: If cancer is confirmed
content.description: Your doctor will assign a cancer stage, which describes how far the cancer has spread, tumor size and aggressiveness, and severity grading.

content.title: Key Point
content.description: Early detection significantly improves treatment success.

content.value: Treatment depends on the stage and grade of the cancer, your overall health, and your personal preferences.

items.title: Surgery
items.description: Hysterectomy (removal of uterus) is the most common treatment. May include removal of ovaries and fallopian tubes.

items.title: Radiation Therapy
items.description: High-energy rays to destroy cancer cells. May be external beam or internal (brachytherapy).

items.title: Chemotherapy
items.description: Drugs to kill cancer cells. Often used for advanced or recurrent cancer.

items.title: Hormone Therapy
items.description: Progesterone or other hormones to slow cancer growth. May be an option for early-stage cancers.

content.value: While not all cases can be prevented, certain measures can reduce your risk.

items.text: Manage diabetes and blood sugar levels
Discuss hormone therapy options with your doctor
Report any unusual bleeding to your doctor promptly

content.value: The most important points to remember about endometrial cancer

content.title: What You Should Know
content.description: Endometrial cancer is often detected early because it causes clear warning signs, especially postmenopausal bleeding. Early diagnosis leads to excellent outcomes, and lifestyle factors like weight management play a significant role in reducing risk.

items.text: Postmenopausal bleeding should never be ignored
Early detection significantly improves treatment success
Maintaining a healthy weight reduces risk
Managing PCOS and hormonal balance is important
Regular gynecological check-ups help catch changes early

content.title: Final Message
content.description: Staying aware of warning signs, attending regular check-ups, and seeking medical evaluation promptly if anything feels unusual can make a significant difference in protecting your health.
